perturbation.original_text: Distributor may return Products to Vendor for credit or full reimbursement, as the case may be, only pursuant to this Section 8.
perturbation.changed_text: Distributor may return Products to Vendor at Vendor's sole discretion.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the consumer's right to return defective products, directly contradicting consumer protection laws that mandate remedies for faulty goods. The modified text gives the Vendor absolute power over returns, violating consumer rights in the EU and Canada.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Consumer Rights Act 2015 (UK), Sale of Goods Act (Ontario, Canada)

perturbation.original_text: Vendor warrants to Distributor that the Products shall perform without manufacturing failure and are fit for purpose. Distributor, in cooperation with Vendor will remedy any defect in the Product in accordance with Section 8.
perturbation.changed_text: Vendor warrants that the Products shall perform without manufacturing failure. The Vendor may attempt to remedy any defect in the Product.
perturbation.explanation: This weakens the warranty by changing the obligation to remedy defects into a discretionary action. By removing 'fit for purpose' it makes the vendor have no guarantee the product is of merchantable quality, which goes against sale of goods act.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Consumer Rights Act 2015 (UK), Sale of Goods Act (Ontario, Canada)

perturbation.original_text: Disputes under this Agreement shall be resolved through arbitration in Ontario, Canada by a single arbitrator to be appointed by agreement of the parties, or in default, by the President of the Law Society/Bar of Canada. The laws of Ontario, Canada shall govern the conduct of the arbitration and any appeal from the decision of the arbitrator.
perturbation.changed_text: Disputes under this Agreement shall be resolved in a manner solely determined by Vendor.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provides for arbitration in Ontario, Canada, which assumes certain consumer protections and legal processes. By replacing it with a clause that gives the Vendor sole discretion over dispute resolution, the contract could potentially bypass consumer protection laws relating to fair dispute resolution processes. In Ontario, Canada, legislation dictates minimum standards of fairness, which are effectively negated by this change.
